benchmark_details.name: Premise Critique Bench (PCBench)
benchmark_details.overview: PCBench is a comprehensive benchmark designed to evaluate the Premise Critique Ability of large language models (LLMs) by incorporating problems with four categories of logical inconsistencies across three levels of difficulty.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To systematically evaluate the premise critique abilities of large language models (LLMs).
purpose_and_intended_users.limitations: The dataset is limited to English and Chinese, which may overlook language-specific logical structures and cultural nuances.

data.source: Curated using mathematical reasoning problems with logical inconsistencies and misleading information.
data.annotation: Manual annotation and error injection strategies.

methodology.calculation: Metrics are calculated based on models' ability to identify and articulate errors in input premises in various scenarios and difficulty levels.
methodology.interpretation: High scores in proactive metrics indicate strong autonomous premise critique ability, while large discrepancies between proactive and assisted rates suggest heavy reliance on external prompts.
methodology.validation: Evaluated 15 representative LLMs against the benchmark.

targeted_risks.demographic_analysis: The benchmark explicitly measures performance across different error types and task complexities, providing insights into demographic fairness across model responses.
targeted_risks.harm: Identifying flawed premises and implications in reasoning tasks.
